urn:contentItem:62NJ-FH31-F0HF-818R-00000-00Mayor: Time for water sustainability action is now2021-05-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A6Mayor: Time for water sustainability action is nowBlack Press Media

The time is up for more studies on how to better protect water quality and sustainability in the North Okanagan watershed, says Vernon Mayor Victor Cumming.

“We already know the basic actions that have to be done,” said Cumming.

He said the “urgency and magnitude” of the issue will only become greater a decade from now, particularly as the impact of climate change continues to become more prevalent across the Okanagan Valley.

Cumming made the comments at the annual general meeting for the Okanagan Basin Water Board, following a presentation by Ted Zimmerman, executive director of the provincial water protection and sustainability branch.

Zimmerman is heading up the development of the Watershed Security Strategy and Fund, a provincial initiative to help synthesize water management along with health and land use directives under one strategy and provide the funding to meet those goals.

Cumming said as a water purveyor, the City of Vernon has been caught up in conflicts with forestry land-use decisions on the Aberdeen Plateau, where the Duteau Creek water intake supplies 60 per cent of the water services for the area.

A nearby cutblock was to be harvested by Tolko raising concerns with the city, but last week an agreement was reached to not allow any harvesting or road construction in the area of concern, which comes within 500 metres of the Duteau Creek water intake.

“My suggestion is we don’t have to study this for two or

three years along parallel land use lines. We know what can happen in the short-term and we have to get to work on protecting these streams immediately… not wait until a catastrophic forest fire occurs in our watershed,” Cumming said.

“There is no use sitting here waiting for new legislation to come forward that might be two or three years out yet when we know now what needs to be done.”

Zimmerman responded that he valued the feedback from Cumming and other municipal and water management use officials at this stage of the strategy consultation process, noting the real impact of climate change,

already felt in the Okanagan over the last five years, which will help expedite the legislation process.

“We are no longer talking about climate change in conceptual terms,” he said.

Lake Country Mayor Jim Baker also participated in the OBWB annual general meeting forum, citing his district’s concerns about not limiting land access or licensing to reservoir foreshore property.

At one point, fishing and hunting along with summer cabin licensing was allowed on reservoir property, but the former Liberal provincial government opened that door more by opening up applications for cabin lease prop-

erty agreements and property acquisition.

“That was eventually taken off the table because of hard lobbying by local governments, but because it was seen as a source of revenue, it has not completely gone away… we sure don’t want to see those areas sold off,” Baker said.

Another concern is mudboggers ripping up reservoir foreshore land and near upshore dams when water levels recede.

Zimmerman acknowledged recreation land use values are part of the discussion in coming up with a water sustainability strategy.

“Your points are noted and we will look in that,” he told Baker.

urn:contentItem:5Y1J-4Y71-F103-30WR-00000-00What's going on here? New radio communication tower in Mississauga2020-01-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1What's going on here? New radio communication tower in Mississauga

Mississauga's Rathwood neighbourhood could be getting a new-radio communication tower and antenna.

Just The Facts

Municipal power utility Alectra is proposing the tower, which would be just over 38 metres tall (approximately 125 feet), and located on Forest Fire Lane southeast of Cawthra Road and Eastgate Parkway.

According to a public notice for the project, the tower would help improve communication between power generation and distribution sites servicing the company's customers and Alectra's control centre.

The notice for the project also said Alectra couldn't find an existing tower that met requirements for access and had space for the antenna system.

Telecommunication tower and antenna facilities are federally regulated, and Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada will decide whether the tower will be constructed.

If built the tower will have to comply with Health Canada's Safety Code 6 at all times. The code sets safe human exposure limits for radiofrequency fields - like those emitting from broadcasting and cell towers - between three kilohertz to 300 gigahertz.

Public comments related to the project can be sent until Jan. 30 to Novanet Communications limited at gosborne@novanetcomm.com

urn:contentItem:62N3-BM51-DYRK-D07V-00000-00Minister of Transport introduces new funding programs to support Canada's airports2021-05-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:12ZLexisNexisMinister of Transport introduces new funding programs to support Canada's airports

OTTAWA, ON, May 11, 2021 /CNW/ - The global COVID-19 pandemic has had an unprecedented impact on the air sector in Canada. Airports have been significantly affected, experiencing major decreases in traffic over the past 15 months. Despite these consequences, airports have played a crucial role since the start of the pandemic by continuing to provide essential air services, including traveling to medical appointments, air ambulance services, community resupply, getting goods to market, search and rescue operations, and forest fire response.

Today, the Minister of Transport, the Honourable Omar Alghabra, launched two new contribution funding programs to help Canada's airports recover from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic:

The Airport Critical Infrastructure Program (ACIP) is a new program providing close to $490 million to financially assist Canada's larger airports with investments in critical infrastructure-related to safety, security or connectivity; The Airport Relief Fund (ARF) is a new program providing almost $65 million in financial relief to targeted Canadian airports to help maintain operations.

In addition to launching these two new funding programs, the Minister announced that Transport Canada's Airports Capital Assistance Program (ACAP) is receiving a funding top-up of $186 million over two years. The ACAP is an existing contribution funding program which provides financial assistance to Canada's local and regional airports for safety-related infrastructure projects and equipment purchases.

Quote

"Canada's airports are major contributors to our country's economy, and play a key role in sustaining the social and economic well-being of our communities, and our local airport workers. These programs will help ensure that, as Canada works towards recovery and travel restart post pandemic, our airports remain viable and continue to provide Canadians with safe, reliable and efficient travel options, while creating and maintaining good paying jobs in the airport sector."

The Honourable Omar AlghabraMinister of Transport

urn:contentItem:634B-7921-F11P-X1NC-00000-00Rockland Resources Pauses Exploration at Cole Gold Mines Project, Red Lake, Ontario Due to Forest Fires2021-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:12ZLexisNexisRockland Resources Pauses Exploration at Cole Gold Mines Project, Red Lake, Ontario Due to Forest FiresACCESSWIRE

VANCOUVER, BC / ACCESSWIRE / July 12, 2021 / Rockland Resources Ltd. (the "Company" or "Rockland") (CSE:RKL) reports that exploration at the Cole Gold Mines Property has been paused due to forest fire activity west of Red Lake. Several forest fires are currently active 10 to 30 km west of the Cole Property. Of these fires, Fire 77 is significant in that has the potential to reach the west shore of Red Lake and make the situation unsafe for work on the Cole Property. Company personnel had been in communication with the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF) Red Lake Fire Management Headquarters and on July 11, 2020 the MNRF requested that all of the Company's personnel vacate the site.

All of Rockland Resources' staff and contractors have been demobilized from the Project and are safe and accounted for. The Property is not in immediate danger from forest fires, however, the Company is monitoring the situation closely. Subject to the resumption of safe working conditions, the drilling program announced on July 7, 2021 is currently planned to restart on July 25, 2021. The Company would like to thank Bow Narrows Camp, Red Lake, for their support in the demobilization.

About the Cole Gold Mines Property

Rockland Resources Ltd. is acquiring a 100-per-cent interest in the Cole Gold Mines Property, located in Ball township, Red Lake Mining Divison, Ontario. The Property consists of 28 mining claims (568 ha) located 30 km west of the Cochenour, Campbell, Red Lake mine complex owned and operated by Evolution Mining. The Property represents a rare opportunity to explore a strategically located asset in one of the most active, prolific producing mining districts in Canada. The property hosts high-grade gold values in a classic Red Lake-type quartz vein and silica-sulphide replacement zones.

About Rockland Resources Ltd.

Rockland Resources is engaged in the business of mineral exploration and the acquisition of mineral property assets in Canada. Its objective is to locate and develop economic precious and base metal properties of merit and to conduct its exploration program on the properties. In addition to the Cole Gold Property, Rockland is exploring the Summit Old Timer Property that consists of three (3) mineral claims covering an area of 1,915 hectares located approximately 17 km southeast of the City of Nelson, within the Nelson Mining Division, British Columbia.

urn:contentItem:62MV-NK21-JBVR-3083-00000-00Ten years later: Five things to know about the Slave Lake wildfire2021-05-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:12ZLexisNexisNATIONALTen years later: Five things to know about the Slave Lake wildfireColette DerworizThe Canadian Press

A wildfire burned about one-third of Slave Lake in northern Alberta in May 2011. Nearly 400 homes and businesses, including an apartment complex, were reduced to ash and rubble when fierce winds whipped flames through town with little warning.

Here are five things we've learned about that fire 10 years ago:

How did the wildfire happen?

The Slave Lake wildfire burned through the town from May 14 to May 16, 2011.

Officials with the Alberta government announced in November 2011 that an unknown arsonist recklessly or deliberately ignited the forest fire.

Damages were pegged at $700 million — one of the country's costliest disasters.

How long did it take to clean up?

Mayor Tyler Warman says many milestones were reached within two years.

The government centre and about 80 per cent of homes were rebuilt. But Warman says it took another four years to finish roads and sidewalks.

"We waited a couple years for people to finish construction."

Warman says there was a list of projects and they slowly checked them off.

"When I look around the community, I see things rebuilt. I see new investment. I see new businesses."

How did it affect the town's residents?

Warman says the population hasn't changed a whole lot since the fire.

The No. 1 factor that saved the community, he says, was temporary housing that was built for residents while they rebuilt their homes.

"It was the difference between success and failure. Without it, we would have been decimated."

Warman says some single people and young couples who were living in the apartment complex left, but school enrolment numbers were steady the next fall.

"There was a pretty strong indication that the people were still here."

Research done after the fire showed some residents with psychological stress symptoms — particularly children. The study suggested children involved in disasters be offered counselling and assistance in recovery.

What have we learned about wildfires?

Mike Flannigan, a renewable resources professor at the University of Alberta, says the Slave Lake fire has left a legacy.

"Fire management in Canada is among the best in the world and Alberta is among the best in Canada," he says. "What has become clear is that events like Slave Lake aren't isolated events.

"One of the politicians of the day was in the paper saying it was a one-off. It was a fluke. It won't happen again. I said the day after ... expect more events like this, unfortunately.'

"It's all about the extreme conditions."

He says the fires in Slave Lake, Fort McMurray, Alta., and Kelowna, B.C., led to politicians paying attention.

Did anything change afterward?

Flannigan says there has been more federal funding for wildfire research.

"Things have changed, but we still need to do more," he says. "It's not going away with climate change."

He says more structures will be at risk if development continues in the boreal forest.

Warman adds those developments need to be prepared for emergencies and for recovery after disasters.

"A good plan is better than a quick plan."

This report by The Canadian Press was first published May 9, 2021.

urn:contentItem:634G-TNY1-DY9S-T4YP-00000-00Firefighters make progress against big fires in US West2021-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:12ZLexisNexisBUSINESS,INTERNATIONALFirefighters make progress against big fires in US WestJohn Antczak And Christopher WeberThe Associated Press

LOS ANGELES (AP) — Dozens of wildfires burned across the torrid U.S. West on Monday but fire agencies reported some progress in corralling the flames and forecasters predicted a gradual decrease in extreme temperatures.

The fires have forced evacuations in numerous areas with dispersed properties and tiny communities where some burned homes and other structures have been observed but total losses were still being tallied.

The fires erupted as the West was in the grip of the second bout of dangerously high temperatures in just a few weeks, and the entire region is suffering from intense drought. The National Weather Service said, however, that the heat wave appeared to have peaked in many areas and excessive-heat warnings were largely expected to expire by Monday night or Tuesday.

The two largest fires were burning forests in northeastern California and southern Oregon, sending smoke across other states.

The Beckwourth Complex, two lightning-ignited blazes, covered about 140 square miles (362 square kilometers) on Northern California’s border with Nevada. Plumas National Forest officials said firefighters successfully contained almost a quarter of the blaze but still expected some extreme fire activity.

Evacuation orders and warnings were in effect for remote areas of California’s Lassen and Plumas counties and Nevada’s Washoe County. Some structures were destroyed over the weekend in Doyle, California, a town of about 600 residents.

“A damage assessment team has arrived to validate and assess reports of structures damaged or destroyed,” a forest statement said.

In Oregon, the Bootleg Fire covered 240 square miles (621 square kilometers) in the Fremont-Winema National Forest, near the Klamath County town of Sprague River.

After doubling in size at least twice over the weekend, it grew only incrementally Sunday, a sign of some progress, said Rich Saalsaa, spokesman for the Oregon State Fire Marshal.

“It’s allowed firefighters to build more lines and go on the offensive,” Saalsaa said.

Seven homes and 43 outbuildings have been destroyed in an area on the south end of the blaze, Saalsaa said.

“Most of these places are not within a community per se. Maybe they’re the same postal zone. But it’s kind of scattered out there, very remote,” Saalsaa said.

Some 1,926 homes were within the current evacuation zone, he said, but he didn’t know how many people that includes.

Firefighters were contending with erratic winds, but temperatures were slightly lower.

The Bootleg Fire disrupted service on three transmission lines providing up to 5,500 megawatts of electricity to California, where the state’s grid operator asked for voluntary power conservation from 4 p.m. to 9 p.m. to ease the strain. The timing coincides with decreasing generation from solar facilities as night falls.

Elsewhere, a forest fire started during lightning storms in southeast Washington grew to more than 86 square miles (223 square kilometers). It was 20% contained Monday.

In Idaho, Gov. Brad Little mobilized the National Guard to help fight twin lightning-sparked fires that have together charred nearly 24 square miles (62 square kilometers) of dry timber in the remote, drought-stricken region.

A new fire broke out Sunday afternoon in the Sierra Nevada south of Yosemite National Park and by evening had exploded over more than 6 square miles (15.5 square kilometers), triggering evacuations in areas of two counties. The fire’s size, however, remained unchanged early Monday and was 5% contained. A highway that leads to Yosemite’s southern entrance remained open.

The July heat wave followed an unusual June siege of broiling temperatures in the West. A growing number of scientific studies are concluding that heat waves in some cases can be directly attributed to climate change.

IN1Looking for troubleA Canadian scientist nearly died in the jungle pursuing HIV's origins. After COVID emerged, he set his sights on the lab leak theoryKate Allen Climate Change Reporter


In the dawning days of the new millennium, Michael Worobey staggered out of the Congolese jungle with a cooler full of chimpanzee poop.

Within the first few hours of the expedition, Worobey had impaled his hand on a barbed plant. Unbeknownst to him, the thorn was still lodged deep in his flesh. As Worobey and two other scientists combed the forest for the specimens, his wound began to fester.



His hand turned black, and he spiked a high fever. Discolouration began streaking up his arm.

"I wanted to stay until we had some chimp s--t samples to take back to town," he says.

By the time he left the jungle, Worobey, then a graduate zoology student at Oxford University, was suffering a life-threatening infection. He got treatment and lived. But the senior scientist leading the trip, a pre-eminent evolutionary biologist named Bill Hamilton, was stricken with malaria and died weeks later.

When the cooler full of chimpanzee excrement finally reached Oxford, two vials of urine held the clues to the mystery they had been seeking to solve: the source of pandemic HIV.

Worobey, a Canadian from Salmon Arm, B.C., has devoted his career to tracking the origin of important viruses, especially pandemic ones. He is known both for his meticulousness in teasing secrets out of viral genes, and for his willingness to get his hands dirty - even gangrenous - in the search for evidence beyond the lab.

Worobey's job has sometimes thrust him into the white-hot centre of controversy. His work has been attacked by ambassadors, by rappers, and by other scientists.

And that was before COVID-19.

In the hunt for the origins of the current pandemic, amid geopolitical jockeying and online vitriol, Worobey has followed a trail of evidence directly into the centre of the fray.

In May 2021, he signed his name to a letter in the prestigious journal Science that urged researchers to seriously investigate whether the virus that causes COVID was accidentally released from a lab. The letter gave the lab-leak theory a major credibility boost and helped launch it into the mainstream; less than two weeks later, U.S. President Joe Biden announced a 90-day intelligence review of the pandemic's origins.

But in the two years since the letter was published, Worobey's own research has produced some of the most compelling evidence yet that the virus spilled over from wild animals. Among the possible culprits: the previously obscure raccoon dog.

Discovering the origin of a virus, especially a pandemic one, is always more than an academic exercise.

Some of history's most lethal pathogens have been controlled by following the path of infection back to its source: a flea-infested colony of rats, for the Black Plague, or a contaminated water pump on London's Broad Street, in the case of cholera.

Pandemics are also world-shifting events, and these investigations are always embedded in the same societies just decimated by an invisible reaper. Competing viral origin stories absorb the miasma of fear, anger and guilt left in the plague's wake, making it even harder to tease out the truth.

The COVID origins debate is often framed as a geopolitical battle: China vs. U.S.A., Republicans vs. Democrats. Between politicians rambling bout nucleotides, epidemiologists blaming dark conspiracies, and how every fact gets refracted in the funhouse mirror that is Twitter, it can be hard to tell which theory has the upper hand. Some people say we will likely never know the truth.

Worobey doesn't say that.

"When we look at the big picture of all of the evidence," he says, "it's like a bright red arrow flashing: 'This is where it started.' "

New ways to unlock

viruses' secrets

Worobey, 50, who heads the University of Arizona's ecology and evolutionary biology department, often uses forest fire analogies to talk about disease outbreaks. Wildfires are always throwing off sparks. If a spark hits a rock or water, it dies. But if a spark hits a patch of dry grass, it can quickly spread out of control.

He would know: as a university student, Worobey spent his summers working for the B.C. Wildfire Service's Rapattack crew, an elite team of firefighters based out of Salmon Arm, his hometown in the province's interior. Members of the Rapattack team are trained to rappel from helicopters and battle hard-to-access blazes.

Aside from being "absolutely the best" college job ever, he says, Worobey's experience with the Wildfire Service offered an unexpected boost into some of the most cutting-edge virus research of the era.

As an undergraduate student at Simon Fraser University, Worobey applied for the Rhodes Scholarship, an international program that brings students to study at Oxford. The scholarship is famously selective, and beyond high grades, screens for candidates who excel in sports or the arts, especially in team settings. The Rhodes people asked a lot of questions about Rapattack, he remembers. He got in.

When he arrived at Oxford in 1997, Worobey joined the zoology department, but wasn't sure what specifically he would focus on. A virologist and evolutionary biologist named Eddie Holmes asked if he wanted to study dengue, an emerging virus transmitted by mosquitoes.

"Mike came in as this very quiet, kind of mild-mannered, gentle, quite unassuming PhD student from Canada, who was very hard-working and had a quiet determination to get things done," says Holmes.

"Next thing you know he's off in the Congo with Bill Hamilton sampling chimpanzees to find the origin of HIV," he says. "You look back in hindsight and think, 'My God. That was bloody mad.' "

Holmes and a small group of colleagues in the department were pioneering ways to force viruses to spill their inner secrets. Computers, genetic sequencing and other molecular tools had all recently become much more powerful. With a flood of genetic data available to analyze, and stronger computational hardware to do it with, scientists were inventing powerful methods of probing viral family trees.

Viruses pick up mutations as they pass from cell to cell. Comparing how similar or different viruses' genome sequences are to each other determines their spot on the family tree, bunching viruses together that are more like sisters and brothers, branching off other groups that are distant cousins, and pinpointing what the ancestor of them all probably looked like, and when it existed.

One of the biggest breakthroughs was applying a "molecular clock" to a family tree. All viruses evolve at different rates. With enough viral samples collected at different time points, the researchers could figure out how many mutations accumulate each month, or year, and then calculate how long ago their most recent common ancestor existed. This can be used to estimate the time the first infection appeared in a region, or even in the world.

"When you put a bunch of these genome sequences together and sort of trace those mutations back, like a reverse Hansel and Gretel breadcrumb trail to the source of things, it just opened up so much more information about how really important pathogens get into humans and then spread," says Worobey.

"It was exciting to have the ability to use the information in the viruses themselves against them."

Worobey had been working with these techniques for a couple years when Hamilton, the famous evolutionary biologist, invited him on an expedition to probe a theory about the origins of HIV.

Not just any theory: the January 2000 trip was a quest to investigate the hypothesis that HIV emerged from, essentially, a botched science experiment.

Unlike Hamilton, Worobey thought the theory was unlikely. But no hypothesis can be refuted without evidence, and Worobey still says the evidence was worth the struggle to get it. That philosophy has echoed throughout the rest of his career - up to, and especially in, the present day.

"I went down there. My colleague died. I almost died. And then I went back again," he says.

"I did have a track record of taking these ideas more seriously than almost anyone else."

How did AIDS spread

around the world?

In the 1950s, a Polish-American researcher named Hilary Koprowski was among the scientists racing to invent the first polio vaccine. Koprowski created an oral vaccine that relied on a weakened version of the virus grown in live cells. He conducted trials for his vaccine in what was then the colonial Belgian Congo and other nearby countries, administering it in nearly a quarter-million people.

Four decades later after Koprowski's trial, a troubling theory took hold.

By 2000, AIDS, HIV's brutal and chameleonic syndrome, had been recognized for almost 20 years. But crucial questions about the virus remained unanswered: How, where and when did it first infect people? And how did it spread across the world?

Scientists had discovered many related viruses in captive and wild African primates, and called these monkey pathogens simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV). Most scientists believed HIV first spread into humans after someone came in contact with an infected chimpanzee through the bushmeat trade.

But a minority of scientists speculated that HIV could have emerged if Koprowski's vaccine trial cultured the weakened viruses it needed in kidney cells from infected chimpanzees. The trial then transmitted the virus directly into people via a contaminated vaccine, the theory held.

Very few researchers working directly on HIV believed this, and Koprowski denied this was how his vaccine was made. But media stories and a popular book inflated the theory's visibility. Hamilton, who was described in an obituary in Nature as "one of the greatest evolutionary theorists since Darwin," became a vocal backer.

In an effort to resolve the question, Hamilton invited Worobey on an expedition, and Worobey invited Jeffrey Joy, another SFU student and Rapattack firefighter. The three of them planned to travel to the part of the Democratic Republic of Congo where, according to the theory, chimpanzees had been collected and used to culture the vaccine. Viral sequences from the chimps' feces could show whether they were carrying a form of SIV directly ancestral to human HIV.

A brutal war was underway in the Congo. "We didn't necessarily 100 per cent know what we were getting into, I think," says Joy, now a senior scientist at the B.C. Centre for Excellence in HIV/AIDS.

Worobey recalls that someone at the Canadian consulate in Uganda, where the trio was trying to find a flight into the DRC, caught wind of the plan, and sent an official to warn that no one could extract the scientists if the situation went south.

Joy remembers boarding a charter plane alongside men wearing fatigues; the pilot, afraid of being shot down, flew to the highest possible altitude and then rapidly descended onto the landing strip.

Once the researchers had negotiated their way into the right area, the trio hiked deep into the jungle; Worobey impaled his hand and didn't seek help for days, a decision he describes in retrospect as "super-stupid. I really was close to dying." By the time they left the country, Hamilton was ill.

Back in London, Hamilton hemorrhaged and was hospitalized, where he remained until he died weeks later. Agonizingly, the cooler of chimpanzee excrement was lost in transit. When it finally arrived, none of the 34 feces samples had viral genetic material. Two of the 10 urine samples showed indirect markers of antibodies against SIV - hints they carried the virus, but not enough information to place it on the HIV family tree.

The trip emphasized something that would stick with Worobey for the rest of his career. Until then, the viral gene sequences he had worked with were mostly collected by doctors and researchers for other reasons.

"For some questions, I just wasn't willing to wait around and hope that someone else would collect the data," he says.

"You're not ever going to get it unless you do it yourself."

Worobey, who got a job at the University of Arizona and his own lab in 2003, went back to the DRC that year.

With more help from Congolese collaborators and local guides and interpreters, the team collected 97 chimpanzee feces samples. At the lab, one sample was positive for SIV.

The analysis revealed that the virus carried by this group of chimpanzees, the ones implicated in Koprowski's polio vaccine, lay on a completely different branch of the family tree than pandemic HIV - a distant cousin. The research was published in Nature with the title "Contaminated polio vaccine theory refuted."

"Putting the final nail in that coffin was really important, in terms of dispelling a myth that was causing a lot of harm," says Joy; the theory had been fanning fears that polio vaccines are unsafe.

Worobey's work showed where HIV didn't come from - but not where it did. He began looking for other samples he could use to illuminate the earliest years of the virus and its global trajectory.

One day, scouring old journal articles from the earliest days of the AIDS pandemic, Worobey found a 1983 paper written by a doctor in Miami named Arthur Pitchenik. It described 20 patients from the city's Haitian community, who on average had been in the country for less than two years, and who showed evidence of "acquired immunodeficiency."

The doctor's phone number was on the manuscript, so Worobey dialed it. Pitchenik "picked up the phone and basically said, 'I've been waiting for someone to contact me about these'" samples, Worobey remembers.

Not long after AIDS was recognized, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control flagged that immigrants from the Haitian diaspora appeared to be disproportionately burdened by the new syndrome. Later on, received wisdom held that sex tourism exported HIV from the U.S. to the small Caribbean island.

But when Worobey got his hands on the specimens from Miami, the virus told a different story. The Haitian immigrants' HIV genome sequences sat deeper on the family tree than those of American patients.

HIV had used the small, impoverished island of Haiti as a stepping stone from Africa into the U.S., the research showed. Worobey's molecular clock analyses suggested it had arrived in North America via a single introduction around 1970.

Worobey knew that the research, published in PNAS in 2007, would touch a raw nerve. But he was not expecting what happened next.

HIV and the human factor

Haiti's ambassador to the U.S. dismissed the validity of the research to reporters. Then Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-born rapper and former member of the Fugees, weighed in.

Jean issued a statement slamming the work, saying it "unjustly targeted our country and showed serious prejudice." Worobey was deluged with slurs and threats, and accused of racism.

"It knocked me pretty hard actually," Worobey says. "For a couple of months, it was pretty bleak."

Some scientists, meanwhile, were incredulous that HIV could have been circulating in the U.S. for 10 or more years without being detected. Soon Worobey would recalibrate the emergence of HIV again.

After tracking down a dusty 1960 biopsy specimen that had been sitting encased in paraffin wax in a closet at the University of Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, Worobey's lab was able to painstakingly tease out viral sequences for analysis. In research published in Nature in 2008, he compared it to the only known older HIV specimen, a sequence from 1959 also taken in what is now Kinshasa.

Worobey pinpointed the last common ancestor, and the emergence of pandemic HIV, to about 1908 - three-quarters of a century before AIDS was first recognized.

Unlike in the COVID-19 pandemic, where these molecular tools could be deployed in almost real time, we will never be able to pinpoint the precise inflection points that allowed HIV to metastasize from a localized epidemic to a global scourge. But the research indicates it wasn't mutations in the viral genome that made a difference - it was changes in human behaviour.

The emergence of HIV in Central Africa coincides with the period when colonial forces were rapidly urbanizing administrative centres like Kinshasa, then called Léopoldville after the king of Belgium. HIV likely needed a big city to sustain itself; without that, it might have fizzled out.

Half a century later, HIV crept into Haiti in the wake of the Congo Crisis of the early 1960s, when Belgian colonizers left abruptly, creating a void of doctors, teachers and other professionals. Hundreds of people from Haiti, a French-speaking former colony that had fought off its own colonial yoke, travelled to Congo to help fill the void.

After the first paper blew up, Worobey was invited to speak on several radio stations that served the Haitian diaspora. He found that if he explained the rationale for the science directly, and stuck to the facts, audiences understood the value of the work.

Among other practical outcomes, the research suggested that vaccines based around the subtype of HIV most commonly found in the U.S. might not work in Haiti, where the virus had time to grow more genetically diverse. And it hinted that if HIV could smoulder along for decades and rely on a couple of unlucky breaks before exploding, it might also be suppressed with antiretroviral therapies and other interventions in the absence of a vaccine.

The exposure also forced Worobey to develop a different kind of immunity, he says.

"It made it a lot easier to deal with all of the abuse, and twisting of the scientific evidence into the opposite of what it's actually saying."

On the trail of COVID-19

On Dec. 30, 2019, a bulletin on ProMED, a global infectious disease notification system, was issued from Hubei province in China. The bulletin described a handful of patients in the city of Wuhan with "pneumonia of unknown cause." The first known patient came from the city's Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, the bulletin said.

Within weeks, Wuhan's hospital was overflowing, the World Health Organization declared a global emergency, and countries started closing borders.

Worobey's wife asked him to talk to their two teenage daughters, expecting him to say everything would be fine.

Instead, "I said, it's inevitable that this is going to affect our lives in a huge way."

(Worobey's wife subsequently shot him "a look of daggers," she confirms. The couple was married shortly before Worobey's first trip to the Congo. Worobey is determined and hard-working, his colleagues say, but he is also a "family man" and "a very likeable, friendly person," according to Holmes: "He doesn't come across as some Indiana Jones type, with a whip and a hat.")

In the middle of 2020, after months in lockdown, Joel Wertheim got a call from Arizona. Wertheim, a professor at University of California San Diego, had been Worobey's first PhD student. Worobey was calling about a piece of software that a graduate student at UCSD had developed to study HIV - he thought it could be useful for COVID.

"One of the most important things he taught me in graduate school was how to identify a problem that everyone else is ignoring or misunderstanding and try and find that one test or that one piece of information that could settle it," Wertheim says.

"He seems to be drawn to controversial research like a moth to a flame," he adds - not for the sake of controversy, but because that's where the answers to the most important scientific questions are.

Wertheim, Worobey and a group of collaborators used the software, along with a molecular clock analysis, to date the earliest likely primary case in China and simulate different ways the epidemic could have grown. It showed that the earliest human-to-human transmission likely occurred between mid-October to mid-November 2019; a later study updated this to mid- to late November.

It also showed that COVID was likely creating transmission chains that went extinct, and required a big enough population centre - Wuhan has 13.6 million residents, significantly more than New York City - for one to catch fire and ignite a pandemic.

The research showed when and how COVID likely emerged. It did not show where.

From the moment officials in China issued that outbreak bulletin, there was good reason to suspect COVID spilled over from animals.

Many disease heavy-hitters are "zoonotic," as pathogens that originate in animals are called: HIV came from chimps; new influenza strains can come from ducks, chicken, pigs and even horses.

The world even got a test run of this pandemic in 2003, when SARS, a respiratory disease caused by a novel coronavirus, emerged from southern China and quickly spread around the world. Toronto was hit hard. A relative of the SARS coronavirus was later detected in palm civets, a cat-like animal; civets from a live animal market and from civet farms tested positive for the virus, as did badgers, cats and a raccoon dog, an animal related to foxes.

The virus that causes COVID is called SARS-CoV-2: SARS, the blockbuster sequel. Viral family trees show that coronaviruses carried by horseshoe bats are ancestral to both.

But there were also features of the new coronavirus and its context that sowed doubts among some scientists.

For Worobey, and for many others, one was that Wuhan, the city where COVID emerged, is home to the Wuhan Institute of Virology, where researchers were studying SARS-related coronaviruses from bats.

From his influenza research, Worobey was also familiar with story of the 1977 "Russian flu." That year, an outbreak of influenza was detected in the Soviet Union. The flu strain went pandemic, but it was unusually mild. Genetic sequences of that strain revealed something strange: it was nearly identical to one that had disappeared 20 years earlier after being displaced by newer flu strains.

Influenza mutates incredibly quickly; that's why the flu vaccine has to be updated every year. A flu that reappears decades after it had last been seen, with almost no changes, cannot be explained by natural viral patterns. It is now generally accepted that this flu strain escaped due to human error.

Throughout 2020, many scientists expressed confidence that COVID spilled over from animals. A letter in the Lancet, a major medical journal, called suggestions that the virus doesn't have a natural origin "conspiracy theories."

Worobey thought a zoonotic origin was more likely, but he wasn't yet convinced.

In conversations with Jesse Bloom, a virologist at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, Worobey discussed the concern that "some of our colleagues were, from my perspective at that point in time, jumping the gun with their level of confidence that it couldn't have been a lab leak."

Worobey suggested publishing something in Science in a March 2021 email to Bloom. Bloom and others, who were also having conversations with each other about the topic, drafted the letter. Worobey and 17 other scientists signed it, and it ran in Science in May.

The lab and animal theories "both remain viable," the letter reads. "We must take hypotheses about both natural and laboratory spillovers seriously until we have sufficient data."

"I was shocked when I saw his name on that," Wertheim says. "I had a lot of colleagues email me saying, 'Did you know Mike was on this letter?' "

Worobey set out to "poke holes in the idea" that the market really was the first cluster.

He requested that the Chinese researcher who had been leading work on SARS-like bat coronaviruses, Shi Zhengli, publish genetic sequences from her work; she did, and none of them were close relatives of SARS-CoV-2.

Then he tried to figure out if the early cluster of cases at the Wuhan seafood market was a mirage - whether a few cases led to a flurry of focused surveillance in one area, when the virus was actually widespread in the city and spreading undetected.

He discovered the opposite: doctors at the Wuhan hospital had noticed a steady trickle of strange pneumonia cases in December, before any link to the market was known; over half of those cases either worked at the market or were otherwise linked there. The other chunk of the earliest known cases, the ones with no link to the market, provided even more compelling clues.

Worobey found a way to reverse-engineer a set of blurry, low-resolution maps of these very early cases included in a WHO report on COVID's origins, extracting the patients' residential locations. The cases with no link to the market were even more likely to be clustered near the market than people with a link, suggesting a wave of infection spreading outwards in the neighbourhood.

In a paper in Science describing that finding published last year, Worobey and his colleagues also found that environmental samples taken from within the market - swabs of cages, carts, freezers and the like - were far more likely to test positive for COVID from the southwest corner of the market. Human cases were more concentrated in that area, too.

Eddie Holmes travelled to Wuhan in 2014 on a research trip and visited this market. In the far southwest corner of the market, he saw stacked cages of wildlife, including a raccoon dog. He snapped a picture, thinking it was a risky place for a zoonotic spillover. Worobey's Science paper confirmed that raccoon dogs, badgers and other animals susceptible to coronaviruses were sold at the market as recently as November 2019.

In another paper, Wertheim, Worobey and others analyzed the diversity of early viruses from Wuhan, and compared two lineages of the virus circulating at the time. The research, also published in Science last year, indicates that these two viruses jumped into humans separately, weeks apart. Both lineages have been detected at the market.

This creates two possible scenarios, as Worobey sees it.

In one, a researcher at the virological institute gets infected during a lab accident. They travel 15 kilometres across the city to the market. They go directly to the area of the market housing wildlife known to be susceptible to coronaviruses and start a transmission chain, while infecting no one else along the way. Two weeks later, another infected lab worker does the exact same thing again.

In the other, wildlife already known to be a risk for carrying coronaviruses infects multiple people at the type of market where humans are continually exposed to them.

The apparent coincidences and analogies that underpinned Worobey's initial thinking now look wobbly to him. COVID needed a big city to catch hold, and the majority of China's biggest cities have major virological institutes, including ones doing coronavirus research. If this had happened in a different city, we would likely suspect those other labs.

The 1977 Russian flu pandemic, he realized, was a strain that had already made the incredibly rare leap from animals to people on its own, and adapted to human-to-human transmission before it was reintroduced by mistake.

It's impossible to account for every volley in the COVID origins debate. Entire books could be written on subjects that sound baffling to anyone not plugged in: the furin cleavage site, the "proximal origin" paper, the gain-of-function debate.

The co-signers of the 2021 Science letter have all plotted different courses: some are convinced by the market research. Some are stridently in support of the lab leak theory. Others say there isn't enough evidence yet to conclude either way: without more data, it's impossible to dismiss the lab leak theory.

"I don't regret that letter," Worobey says. "I think it was good for scientists to say, 'Let's take this theory seriously scientifically." He does, after spending a lot of time taking it seriously, wish in retrospect that the text was clearer that a natural origin was much more likely, because the letter was used to create the impression that it was "a jump ball - 50/50."

Worobey agrees that there are still things we don't know, like which animal the virus jumped from. With scientific evidence, "you're always expressing your confidence in a hypothesis ... nothing has ever been ruled out," he says. People will always be able to come up with scenarios of how the virus moved from the lab to the market - "but what they need to understand is just how improbable to the extent of being implausible those claims are."

Worobey takes no issue with anyone who hasn't assessed the evidence yet - he started there himself. He does take issue with those actively ignoring the full scope of evidence, or worse, distorting it.

The results of the FBI's and other intelligence agencies' reviews, which have offered a range of assessments in where COVID came from and their confidence in those conclusions, are "a huge embarrassment to the intelligence community," Worobey says.

"The U.S. government, and governments in general, are making a huge strategic error and compromising national security by trying to ask our intelligence agencies to answer scientific questions, because they get the wrong answer or no answer at all," he adds, noting that the government, busy pursuing the lab leak, has done nothing to address the "recipe for pandemics" that wildlife markets represent.

"The shots on goal are coming from there constantly, and not from labs," he says.

Meanwhile, on Twitter, extreme voices in the lab leak debate have begun dredging up the polio vaccine theory for AIDS. They suggested that his rejection of the lab leak somehow makes his refutation of the polio theory suspicious.

Worobey thinks that once the dust settles, it will be clear to the broader public, and not just him and his collaborators, that the totality of evidence is on the side of an animal origin for COVID. He also sometimes mentions farms in western Hubei province that according to reports hosted hundreds of thousands of animals, including raccoon dogs, civets and other animals, all liquidated in early 2020.

"Maybe we'll be able to dig up a pit where these animals were buried," he says, "And maybe we'll be able to find traces of the virus that are ancestral to what we see in humans."

urn:contentItem:6349-RT21-JC13-H1WF-00000-00Pauses Exploration at Cole Gold Mines Project, Red Lake, Ontario Due to Forest Fires2021-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:12ZLexisNexisPauses Exploration at Cole Gold Mines Project, Red Lake, Ontario Due to Forest Fires

ROCKLAND RESOURCES LTD ("RKL-Z") - Pauses Exploration at Cole Gold Mines Project, Red Lake, - Ontario Due to Forest Fires

Rockland Resources Ltd. (the "Company" or "Rockland") reports that exploration at the Cole Gold Mines Property has been paused due to forest fire activity west of Red Lake. Several forest fires are currently active 10 to 30 km west of the Cole Property. Of these fires, Fire 77 is significant in that has the potential to reach the west shore of Red Lake and make the situation unsafe for work on the Cole Property. Company personnel had been in communication with the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF) Red Lake Fire Management Headquarters and on July 11, 2020 the MNRF requested that all of the Company's personnel vacate the site.

All of Rockland Resources' staff and contractors have been demobilized from the Project and are safe and accounted for. The Property is not in immediate danger from forest fires, however, the Company is monitoring the situation closely. Subject to the resumption of safe working conditions, the drilling program announced on July 7, 2021 is currently planned to restart on July 25, 2021. The Company would like to thank Bow Narrows Camp, Red Lake, for their support in the demobilization.

About the Cole Gold Mines Property

Rockland Resources Ltd. is acquiring a 100-per-cent interest in the Cole Gold Mines Property, located in Ball township, Red Lake Mining Divison, Ontario. The Property consists of 28 mining claims (568 ha) located 30 km west of the Cochenour, Campbell, Red Lake mine complex owned and operated by Evolution Mining. The Property represents a rare opportunity to explore a strategically located asset in one of the most active, prolific producing mining districts in Canada. The property hosts high-grade gold values in a classic Red Lake-type quartz vein and silica-sulphide replacement zones.

About Rockland Resources Ltd.

Rockland Resources is engaged in the business of mineral exploration and the acquisition of mineral property assets in Canada. Its objective is to locate and develop economic precious and base metal properties of merit and to conduct its exploration program on the properties. In addition to the Cole Gold Property, Rockland is exploring the Summit Old Timer Property that consists of three (3) mineral claims covering an area of 1,915 hectares located approximately 17 km southeast of the City of Nelson, within the Nelson Mining Division, British Columbia.

Richard Sutcliffe

President and Director
